The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pericardial effusion, but there is no evidence of right ventricular compression. The best initial step for treatment is observation and anti-inflammatory medicines, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage may be necessary if there is evidence of cardiac tamponade or if the effusion is causing significant hemodynamic compromise. Pericardiectomy is only necessary in rare cases of recurrent or chronic effusions.
